⊢ ((c0 ∈(Poly ` c1)∧ c2 ∈(Poly ` c1))→(deg `(c0[oF(×)]c2))[≤](c3[+]c4))
⊣ c3 =(deg ` c0)
⊣ c4 =(deg ` c2)
⊣ d(hs1,(coeff ` c0))
⊣ d(hs1,(coeff ` c2))
⊣ d(hs1, c3)
⊣ d(hs1, c4)

cumulated.origin:
|- wi(wa(wcel(c0, cfv(cply, c1)), wcel(c2, cfv(cply, c1))), wbr(cfv(cdgr, co(c0, cof(cmul), c2)), cle, co(c3, caddc, c4)))
-| wceq(c3, cfv(cdgr, c0))
-| wceq(c4, cfv(cdgr, c2))

-| wceq(c3, cfv(cdgr, c0))

-| diffsc(hs1, c4)

-| wceq(c3, cfv(cdgr, c0))

-| wceq(c3, cfv(cdgr, c0))
-| wceq(c4, cfv(cdgr, c2))

comment: The degree of a product of polynomials is at most the sum of degrees. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 24-Jul-2014.)
